Cite or name the source in the<strong> body</strong> of your work.&nbsp; This is an <strong>in-text citation</strong>.<br /><br /><strong>Part 2</strong>:&nbsp;&nbsp; Provide extra detail about the citation in a list of references at the <strong>end</strong> of your work.<br /><br /><img alt=\"For example, the body of your used car article might include the sentence &quot;A 2014 Ford Focus in good condition is worth between $6,200 and $7,300.&quot; followed by Upton comma 2017 in parentheses.  Your list of references provides more detail about Upton's book in an entry that reads Upton comma A period 2017 in parentheses, period, Car value almanac. Detroit, Michigan: Automotive Press.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p><p><br /><em>Note</em>: ONLY the sources that you cite in the body of your work go into the&nbsp;list of references at the end of your writing.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>Readers find your report about buying a used car interesting and useful.<br /><br />Where will they see the two parts of the documentation system?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_a6595ec4-41e7-13f3-353f-f1650f7e9784\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_a659...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>While preparing your article about used cars, you read an article about the impact of climate on the deterioration of a car&#39;s paint and frame.&nbsp; You decide not to include this information in your article.&nbsp; Do you need to include the article in your list of references?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_87cb2af6-075c-aa6f-12c4-56f7c389d57e\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; -moz-user-select: none;\">MC Placeholder<br /><strong>ID: mc_87cb...</strong></jumc><span>&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>There are five reasons why it is important to document your sources:<br /><br /><strong>1.&nbsp; By crediting your sources, you acknowledge ownership of the ideas.</strong><br /><br />Using someone else&#39;s ideas is acceptable; many writers do so. To demonstrate your honesty as a writer, it is important to give credit to those whose ideas you have borrowed.<br /><br />Tara Browning wrote an article for <em>The Consumer Advocate</em> in which she discusses the overall high reliability of cars produced in the last ten years.<br /><br />She wrote:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"color: black; font-family: times new roman,serif; font-size: 14px; width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p>Buying a used car in the 1970s and 1980s was a frightening proposition.&nbsp; You never knew what to expect.&nbsp; A car that looked great on the outside might have had terrible mechanical or electrical problems.&nbsp; Today, when you buy a used car, you can use many sources of information to determine the price, quality, and reliability of each make and model&mdash;for example, the Ford Focus, or Honda Civic. &nbsp;&nbsp;</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Why documenting sources is important"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>You use some of this information when you write about the history of the cars of the 1970s and 1980s.&nbsp;&nbsp; Why do you need to give credit to Tara Browning?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_405e0030-dc53-e066-c0e6-da281c0f671a\" style=\"width: 200px; background: rgb(163, 228, 255) none repeat scroll 0% 0%; The in-text citations are indicated with highlighting:</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain\" style=\"width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"ju-double-space\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:15px;line-height:180%;\">Used-car buyers today can find some consolation in the fact that today&#39;s cars are much better mechanically than the cars of earlier generations. &nbsp;&nbsp; As Tara Browning <span class=\"marker\">(2016)</span> notes in an article for <em>The Consumer Advocate</em>, &quot;A car that looked great on the outside might have had terrible mechanical or electrical problems&quot; <span class=\"marker\">(p. 40)</span>.&nbsp; In fact, cars of the 1970s and 1980s were often unreliable or even dangerous <span class=\"marker\">(Browning, 2016)</span>.&nbsp; Cars manufactured after 2000 are light-years ahead of earlier cars in terms of quality and reliability.</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><img alt=\"\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" />&nbsp;See the mini-lesson <em>Basic rules for documenting sources</em> for information about formatting in-text citations.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1,"showRuler":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>2.&nbsp; You give your readers a chance to follow up and read more about what you have told them.</strong><br /><br />Some readers will want to learn more about the topics you wrote about.&nbsp; Documenting your sources allows them to find more information.<br /><br />For information on the differences between buying a used car from a private owner or from a used-car dealer, you consult a blog called <em>The Car Blog</em>.&nbsp; You find an interesting entry on this blog:<br />&nbsp;</p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"color: black; font-family: times new roman,serif; font-size: 14px; width: 90%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>The Car Blog</strong><br />October 20, 2017</p><p><strong>Buying a Used Car from a Dealer</strong></p><p>In the old days, when you wanted to sell a car, you placed an advertisement in the Want Ad section of the newspaper.&nbsp; Interested buyers called you on the phone, made an appointment to test-drive the car, and often wanted their mechanic to evaluate the car.&nbsp; Some buyers chose to buy from used-car lots, many of which had a reputation for selling &quot;lemons.&quot;</p><p>Fast-forward to the 21st century, where car dealerships have a thriving business in selling used cars alongside new ones. What is the dealer&#39;s advantage?&nbsp; Many of them provide a 100-point inspection on the car before putting it on the lot, thus reassuring buyers that the car is of high quality.&nbsp; In addition, dealerships often offer warranties, which car buyers find very desirable.</p></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRuler":0,"showRFB":1},"leftText":"<p>What important piece of information is missing from the blog entry titled &quot;Buying a Used Car from a Dealer&quot;?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><jumc ju-mc=\"mc_30c3d8e9-51dc-c998-ae8d-ca640aabf772\" style=\"width: 200px; You should know the maximum amount that you can pay, including the cost of taxes, licenses, and your registration.&nbsp; You can use several techniques to make sure that you don&#39;t exceed your budget.&nbsp; <span class=\"marker\">As sales expert Gary Wilfred (2004)</span> tells us, &quot;One highly successful technique is called &#39;the broken record.&#39;&nbsp; No matter what the salesperson says, you just keep repeating &#39;I want to pay no more than $X for this car.&#39;&nbsp; By repeating yourself like a broken record, you wear the salesperson down&quot;<span class=\"marker\"> (p. 12)</span>.</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p>&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":0,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"showRFB":1,"showRuler":1},"leftText":"<p><strong>4.&nbsp; You avoid plagiarism.</strong><br /><br />Plagiarism is using the&nbsp;words or ideas of someone else and passing them off as your own. &nbsp; Plagiarism can be either</p><ul style=\"padding-left:15px;\"><li><strong>intentional</strong>, when you knowingly use another person&#39;s work, OR</li><li><strong>unintentional</strong>, when you do not realize that you need to give credit to sources used.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>In either case, plagiarism is a serious offense.&nbsp;
